div.p: Most people think bungee jumping —as we know it —started in New Zealand.
However a type of bungee jumping started in the small Pacific island nation of Vanuatu.
At first, it looks like traditional bungee jumping, but it is very different.
This is the Naghol, which means "land diving."
The diver tries to touch the soil with his head.
The people of Vanuatu believe this will make their crops grow.
They jump from this 70-foot wooden tower.
High on the tower, one man, Rene, has some advice.
"Whenever you are on the tower ready to jump, if you have second thoughts that means you must not jump."
The first diver greets the crowd like a rock star.
His dive goes well.
He hits the ground hard, but he’s OK.
His friends run to him and free his ankles.
The second dive is not so good.
The young boys think the vines are not good, but the older, more experienced divers say they are OK.
They aren’t.
On the way down, one of the vines breaks and the young boy hits the ground.
Everyone helps. But he’s unconscious.
Jumping is sometimes dangerous.
Sometimes people are seriously injured. But usually they are OK.
At last, the boy is better.
He walks away with his friends and brothers.
One of the older men jumps next.
He is standing on the tower.
Eventually he jumps.
It’s a very good dive.
Westerners aren’t allowed to jump, but we can tie a small camera to a diver’s leg.
We think this is the first time.
The crowd loves it.
"Good job. Yeah, very good, very good."
"Aw, great! You did very good. Are you all OK?"
The young man with the camera tells about his jumps in the local language, Raga.
“The first dive was great. The second dive I broke a vine. But as long as I’m not hurt, everything is going well."
"I’m a lucky man."
The last jump is by one of the most experienced divers in Pentecost.
He jumps from the tower and everyone is happy.
When it’s over, the children climb the tower.
One day, they might jump.
